dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Luckin Coffee's stock surged even after reporting a 20% sales drop to $108.9 million last quarter—how does that make any sense?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Luckin Coffee's stock surged even after reporting a twenty percent sales drop to one hundred eight point nine dollars million last quarter-how does that make any sense?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Luckins stock was also powered upward by a company report earlier this week that its sales in the third quarter soared to $208.9 million, an increase of 558% from a year earlier.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And they've expanded like crazy—3,680 stores now, up from just 1,189 a year ago. That growth is insane, but the losses are piling up too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And they've expanded like crazy-three thousand, six hundred eighty stores now, up from just eleven eighty nine a year ago. That growth is insane, but the losses are piling up too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Luckin by the end of the third quarter had 3,680 stores compared with 1,189 a year earlier.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, their loss widened to $92 million. Yet somehow, chairman Charles Lu is sitting on a fortune worth, what, $1.26 billion now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, their loss widened to ninety two dollars million. Yet somehow, chairman Charles Lu is sitting on a fortune worth, what, one point two six dollars billion now?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fridays stock surge left Luckins market cap at $6.4 billion, and the fortune of chairman Charles Lu (also known as Charles Zhengyao Lu or Lu Zhengyao) worth an estimated $2.26 billion. Luckin is also struggling to make money its loss widened in the third quarter to $82 million (see details here).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And CEO Jenny Qian became a millionaire overnight from her shares. It's wild how much wealth has been created so quickly for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And C E O Jenny Qian became a millionaire overnight from her shares. It's wild how much wealth has been created so quickly for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The big increase in Luckins shares on Friday also turned Luckins CEO Jenny Zhiya Qian into a billionaire, with a holding worth $1.06 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But compare that to Howard Schultz of Starbucks—$5.2 billion. Luckin's market cap is only $5.4 billion, while Starbucks is nearing $100 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But compare that to Howard Schultz of Starbucks-five point two dollars billion. Luckin's market cap is only five point four dollars billion, while Starbucks is nearing one hundred dollars billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fridays stock surge left Luckins market cap at $6.4 billion, and the fortune of chairman Charles Lu (also known as Charles Zhengyao Lu or Lu Zhengyao) worth an estimated $2.26 billion. Lus and Qians fast-rising wealth compares with a fortune of $4.2 billion for Howard Schulz, Starbucks iconic founder and former chairman.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but you gotta admit, for a company founded in 2017, they're making huge waves in China—Starbucks' key market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but you gotta admit, for a company founded in twenty seventeen, they're making huge waves in China-Starbucks' key market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares in Luckin, which was founded in only 2017 and is headquartered in the southeastern Chinese city of Xiamen, have now climbed more than 59% since the company went public in May this year at a price of $17 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. They went public in May at $27 a share and have dropped over 9% since, but investors still seem optimistic?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. They went public in May at twenty seven dollars a share and have dropped over nine percent since, but investors still seem optimistic?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares in Luckin, which was founded in only 2017 and is headquartered in the southeastern Chinese city of Xiamen, have now climbed more than 59% since the company went public in May this year at a price of $17 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like there's this belief that growth will eventually turn into profit, but with losses widening, I'm not so sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like there's this belief that growth will eventually turn into profit, but with losses widening, I'm not so sure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And all this happening against the backdrop of U.S.-China tensions—it's almost symbolic, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all this happening against the backdrop of U.S.-China tensions-it's almost symbolic, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Perhaps the same can be said these days for the overall U.S.-China relationship.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like this aggressive Chinese challenger taking on an American giant. You can't ignore the geopolitical angle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like this aggressive Chinese challenger taking on an American giant. You can't ignore the geopolitical angle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, expanding store count that fast… I wonder how sustainable it really is long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, expanding store count that fast... I wonder how sustainable it really is long-term.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. They're headquartered in Shenzhen, right? That hustle culture might be driving it, but the numbers don't lie—they're burning cash.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. They're headquartered in Shenzhen, right? That hustle culture might be driving it, but the numbers don't lie-they're burning cash.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares in Luckin, which was founded in only 2017 and is headquartered in the southeastern Chinese city of Xiamen, have now climbed more than 59% since the company went public in May this year at a price of $17 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think they can ever actually rival Starbucks globally, or is this just a regional play?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think they can ever actually rival Starbucks globally, or is this just a regional play?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to say. Starbucks has such a strong brand, but in China? Luckin's already a force.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to say. Starbucks has such a strong brand, but in China? Luckin's already a force.

artist_script:
HostA: So, Luckin Coffee's stock surged even after reporting a 20% sales drop to $108.9 million last quarter—how does that make any sense?
HostB: Right? And they’ve expanded like crazy—3,680 stores now, up from just 1,189 a year ago. That growth is insane, but the losses are piling up too.
HostA: Yeah, their loss widened to $92 million. Yet somehow, chairman Charles Lu is sitting on a fortune worth, what, $1.26 billion now?
HostB: Exactly! And CEO Jenny Qian became a millionaire overnight from her shares. It’s wild how much wealth has been created so quickly for them.
HostA: But compare that to Howard Schultz of Starbucks—$5.2 billion. Luckin’s market cap is only $5.4 billion, while Starbucks is nearing $100 billion.
HostB: True, but you gotta admit, for a company founded in 2017, they’re making huge waves in China—Starbucks’ key market.
HostA: Oh, absolutely. They went public in May at $27 a share and have dropped over 9% since, but investors still seem optimistic?
HostB: It feels like there’s this belief that growth will eventually turn into profit, but with losses widening, I’m not so sure.
HostA: And all this happening against the backdrop of U.S.-China tensions—it’s almost symbolic, isn’t it?
HostB: Yeah, like this aggressive Chinese challenger taking on an American giant. You can’t ignore the geopolitical angle.
HostA: Still, expanding store count that fast… I wonder how sustainable it really is long-term.
HostB: For sure. They’re headquartered in Shenzhen, right? That hustle culture might be driving it, but the numbers don’t lie—they’re burning cash.
HostA: Do you think they can ever actually rival Starbucks globally, or is this just a regional play?
HostB: Hard to say. Starbucks has such a strong brand, but in China? Luckin’s already a force.
